  \cellcolor{green!27}\small A word about Subutex and Suboxone (which starts out as Subutex, but contains naloxone to discourage patients from injecting it): I've been on it a few times as three-week tapers (to get me over the worst of my painkiller withdrawals, but tapering almost immediately so my body wouldn't become dependent on Suboxone instead), because that is my HMO's procedure for helping with the initial detox. They will refer to methadone clinics if repeated tapers are unsuccessful. It blocked cravings and sickness just as well as methadone, but without the heat intolerance that I still experience on methadone. I ended up on methadone because I just couldn't deal with the withdrawal symptoms after the Suboxone tapers ended, and would relapse on Oxy right away. Methadone maintenance has an advantage in that it's a clinically supervised program, and if people are still 'using on top' then their doctor will adjust their dosage and their counselor should help them explore what triggers them to use. You have to accept that on the right dosage, you will not experience euphoria (after the first week, anyway), and the point is to feel 'normal', not sick but not buzzed either. Suboxone is a partial opioid agonist, so there is a 'glass ceiling effect' when it comes to highs and there is less potential for it being abused. But it's expensive, and many states still have a 'cap' or limit on how many \textbf{doctors} can legally prescribe it. Methadone is a full agonist; it's possible to get high on it if the dose is regularly increased (but that defeats the purpose of treatment!). Induction is slow to reduce the possibility of overdose. I've only had to go up five mg in the three years I've been on it, and that was because it was absent from my blood levels on a few tests. Methadone is much cheaper, you don't have to scramble to find a doctor to renew your prescription if your Sub doctor retires or stops subscribing it, and most of us are not handcuffed to the building. Take-home dose privileges are an incentive to follow the clinic's rules, and that's the point of maintenance treatment: to live as normal a life as possible. Whether someone ends up on methadone or Subs has a lot to do with income level and how long they've been addicted to opiates. But they both have pros and cons, and some people do much better on one than the other.\normalsize   & \cellcolor{green!27}doctors & \cellcolor{green!27}Nationality - General & \cellcolor{green!27}1/410 & \cellcolor{green!27}0.244 \\  \hline
